choices.A: Missing secure flag for a sensitive cookie

discussion.content:
adding cookies to static content makes little sense.
Although the question does not say it, a static website is likely to be a cookieless website.
A cookieless domain, as the name implies, are domains that don’t serve cookies. 
If you were to visit a website on a cookieless domain, cookies won’t be sent to your browser.

A. Missing secure flag for a sensitive cookie?? # IMO, there are none sensitive cookies like usernames/passwords on a static website due to the website does not use a database in first place.
F. Command injection # It's not possible to inject a payload because is not an interactive dynamic website that(PHP for example)


What are some examples of information disclosure?
Revealing the names of hidden directories, their structure, and their contents via a robots.txt file or directory listing.
https://portswigger.net/web-security/information-disclosure
This is possible on a static website.

comments.content:
Note that the question never says the website is static; only that the page is. It is entirely possible to be served a static page by the server while still also having a cookie created. In fact, just by browsing to the website itself, cookies could be created that contain sensitive information. Bottom line: just because the webPAGE is static, does not mean the webSITE is. Cookies are entirely possible.

B and F are the correct answers, in my opinion.
100% agree those two attacks are not possable as the site doesnt have any interaction options to take advantage of.

discussion.content:
B. Reflected cross-site scripting
F. Command injection

Selected Answer: BF
looks good to me

Rather than consider the static page definition, let's consider what a dynamic page can do and then we can find the options that, had they appeared on a static site scan would indicate a false positive. 
Reflected XSS should not be possible on a page that isn't processing data from the person visiting the page, so that's a dynamic page only problem.
Command injection should also not be possible on a page that isn't taking user input and doing something with it.
Keep in mind this might be a single static page among a site with 30 other dynamic pages, so with that in mind, when scanning this single static page these things could be present:
Cookies are site specific so sure you could have an insecure cookie.
Directory listing, depends if you consider a directory list dynamic or not, but generally the contents aren't changing.
insecure http, sure https or http, nothing about a static page rules this out.
Disclosure of sensitive info, sure, what if it said we're running Apache x.y.z?
Weak ciphers, sure, why not?

questions.question_text: Which of the following vulnerabilities are MOST likely to be false positives when reported by an automated scanner on a static HTML web page? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
looks good to me
I think answer A vaguely encompasses answer D as well, so I think A is the better answer.

Go D, since implementer biggest concern should be "did i do it wrongly?"
But then again D isn't a vul.. as always with the confusion.

From this confusing question, I guess that the on-prem environment "never" had such an issue prior to this migration. 
As a result, I am assuming that the onboarding of this new application may have been misconfigured, and caused some security issues. 
I would say that the new service is an unsecured service, but that is something they SHOULD have checked out (SAST) prior to the migration. This is a tough one. I think I'll go with 
D - Misconfiguration

comments.content:
As per the exam objectives, the 3.4 application-based vulnerabilities has:
Security misconfiguration:
- Directory traversal
- Cookie manipulation

and 3.5 local host vulnerabilities has:
- Unsecure service and protocol configurations

So what vulnerabilities are we trying the replicate to the VM? If that is what the question is. From the new application software or from the on-premises environment?

Actually I think it's D as the tester is replicating the same environment so he can pentest the vulnerabilities from the new application. 

CompTIA PenTest_ Certification Passport (Exam PT0-001) - Heather Linn
"Application testing may also include evaluation of misconfigurations to the servers hosting the application. These misconfigurations may affect the confidentiality of the application data or allow testers to tamper with individual user sessions. Three examples of this type of vulnerability are directory traversal, file inclusion, and cookie manipulation."
Very confusing. Or should it be which is the MOST important factor for the pentest to replicate to the VM in order to perform pentesting? Not sure about this one.

discussion.content: What is this question asking? What vulnerabilities are the most important to eliminate?

questions.question_text:
A software development team recently migrated to new application software on the on-premises environment. Penetration test findings show that multiple vulnerabilities exist. If a penetration tester does not have access to a live or test environment, a test might be better to create the same environment on the VM.
Which of the following is MOST important for confirmation?

choices.C: Weak password complexity and user account

questions.question_text: A tester has captured a NetNTLMv2 hash using Responder. Which of the following commands will allow the tester to crack the hash using a mask attack?

discussion.content:
I would go for C.

https://laconicwolf.com/2018/09/29/hashcat-tutorial-the-basics-of-cracking-passwords-with-hashcat/

-m 5600 --> specifies NetNTLMv2 as the hash type
-a 3 --> specifies a mask attack, 
hash.txt --> file containing the hashes
?a?a?a?a?a?a?a?a --> this particular mask will attempt to bruteforce an 8 character password where all characters can be uppercase, lowercase, digits and can have space, symbols, etc.

https://www.4armed.com/blog/perform-mask-attack-hashcat/
https://hashcat.net/wiki/doku.php?id=hashcat
https://hashcat.net/wiki/doku.php?id=mask_attack
https://www.cyberpratibha.com/hashcat-tutorial-for-password-cracking/

Selected Answer: C
looks good to me
It was on the exam

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has been asked to conduct a penetration test on a REST-based web service. Which of the following items is required?

choices.D: A list of sample test accounts
choices.B: A list of sample application requests
choices.C: An up-to-date list of possible exploits

discussion.content: Answer is B
the answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me

Agree with B. 
You need to get a basic understand of what the Rest Interface is doing.

If you job is do simulate a real attacker, you also don't need accounts.

D is the most accurate answer, because having sample test accounts will allow the pentester to conduct both authenticated and non-authenticated pentesting. Also:
- The latest vulnerability scan results (is irrelevant)
- A list of sample application requests (can be generated by the pentester)
- An up-to-date list of possible exploits(it is the pentester job to find these things)

Maybe D. A list of sample test accounts? 
A pentester can do A, B, or C, without *requiring* anything. But if the pentester cannot log into the application, he/she cannot test anything. 
For example, let's say you need to test a banking app. You can run your own vulnerability tests. Maybe look for exploits. You can also make your application requests. You can do all that once you have logged in. But you might not be able to find a way to log in.

comments.content:
Guessing it would be quicker if the customer provided a list of SAR instead of generating or/and even capturing them with apps like Postman, mentioned on the website below:
https://www.mindpointgroup.com/blog/cyber-security/rest-assured-penetration-testing-rest-apis-using-burp-suite-part-1-introduction-configuration/ 

"For whitebox and greybox tests, we could have full documentation, use-case scenarios, and even stock JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) request tokens outlining the structure of the HTTP packets the API accepts. For blackbox tests, however, we’ll have to build our packets through trial and error using API debugging/mapping tools, such as Postman, and by capturing valid requests/responses using Burp Suite as a proxy service. Due to time constraints of most tests, it’s usually more cost effective to aim for whitebox tests. Whitebox tests provide the assessor with all the information they need so they can correctly identify and focus on attacking the weakest links as quickly and effectively as possible."

Anyway, if it's a whitebox test, the customer would also have to provide the test accounts so, not sure about this one.
The sample requests might contain accounts. Apart from that if once you got the sample accounts, you can do nothing about that.
The answer is B...a few questions back we had a similar one about SOAP. I copied the proof there. It contained info about REST.

discussion.content: Perhaps B? - https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2018/01/understanding-using-rest-api/

Selected Answer: CD
looks good to me
It was on the exam

D is 1 answer, I just tried it manually and just changing that it returns true, both C and D can be done and it stills returns true, so it’s s your choice at this point. Removing the let does not causes an error.
This is the one i tried

source=10
dest=5+5
if [ $source -eq $dest ]; then
echo "True"
else
echo "False"
fi
returns : True

C and D. Removing the let causes an error. Just put this in a bash tester and see for yourself. 
#!/bin/bash

source=10
let dest=5+5

if [ $source -eq $dest ]; then
 echo "True"
else
 echo "False"
fi
#End of file

comments.content: I think this is the correct answer. In Bash the let command evaluates the math expression. If you remove that the script will not return true. The script will still run, but it will return false as the the dest variable will not evaluate to 10. The one you absolutely have to change is the $source and $dest. The expression still works with = or -eq, but its the only other answer that doesn't break the script. I am going with C and D.

discussion.content:
it B and D
it can't be C Guys: You need to reference variables with a $ sign in front.
so "source" is just a string ... the reference the stored value you need $source

also the = does not need ot be changed to -eq .
if you type $source=$destination ... the value of $destination will be assigned to $source
but if you leave space like:
$source = $destination
it's used as comparsion operator.

comments.content:
Given this scenario, the word let does not need to be included in the script, so it 
can be removed, and in Bash, the equivalent to an = is -eq, which is the arithmetic binary 
operator. Once these modifications are made, the script will work as expected

C. Change the ג€˜=ג€™ to ג€˜-eqג€™.
